ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I was exposed to a range of ideas from disability studies and learned a lot from other students in the class who had personal and academic interests in the field.
I engaged in critical thinking with this course's material than with that of any other course I have ever taken.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Class discussions were often productive but we didnt always discuss all of the readings. I especially enjoyed Kafers Feminist Queer Crip but we usually didnt spend a lot of time talking about the theoretical issues brought up in that book. I enjoyed the classroom culture as well. All the students were very engaged and respectful of each other.
It would have been nice if the syllabus could have included a bit more global material, but everything that was included in the syllabus was important and was taught well.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I hope Yale offers more disability studies courses in the future. Its a field of study that often isnt addressed in other courses

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Disability studies is such an important field that is too often understudied, and Professor Rogers does an excellent job with the contents of her syllabus.
